entries.content: Selling is a communication skill that requires structure and a game plan to move the prospect from one point to another.
The sales process is designed to move a prospect from intellect to emotion, then back to intellect.
People buy emotionally and justify intellectually. Your job is to find the compelling emotional reason.
Ask the prospect how not fixing the problem makes them feel.
Identify the three biggest symptoms your prospects likely suffer from and ask them if they recognize any.
Talk about what you fix, not what you do.
Selling is about disqualifying: figure out reasons why you can't work together and have the prospect argue why you can.
Get prospects to rule out all alternative solutions until your product or service is what's left.
When a prospect says no, ask one last question to test if it's a real objection or just a brush-off.
entries.notes: Relates to Clarify-Isolate-Overcome concept for handling objections.

entries.content: Use a 30-second 'pain commercial' outlining common problems you fix.
Use a pattern interrupt to get permission to continue the conversation.
Ask a series of questions designed to move the prospect from an intellectual state to an emotional one.
Get permission from the prospect before asking probing questions.
Acknowledge the prospect's likely initial position or feeling, then present a different perspective or outcome.
Use deliberate pauses, emphasis, and delivery to create emotion; selling is acting.
In the valve sales example, identifying specific pains (water ingress, lead times) and asking which one they'd fix demonstrates uncovering emotional drivers.
entries.notes: Illustrates diagnosing pain and moving towards emotion.
